Guide to Jenkins Shared Library Groovy Debugging
can you guide to create jenkins shared library groovy and also how to debug groovy can debug with vscode , indelij

Creating and Debugging Jenkins Shared Libraries in Groovy

Creating a Jenkins Shared Library

1. Library Structure

A basic Jenkins Shared Library has this structure:

Copy
Download
(root)
+- src                     # Groovy source files
|   +- org
|       +- example
|           +- Utilities.groovy
+- vars                    # Global variables/scripts
|   +- myCustomStep.groovy
+- resources               # Non-Groovy files

2. Sample Files

src/org/example/Utilities.groovy

groovy
Copy
Download
package org.example

class Utilities implements Serializable {
    def steps
    
    Utilities(steps) {
        this.steps = steps
    }
    
    def build(String projectName) {
        steps.echo "Building ${projectName}"
        steps.sh "make ${projectName}"
    }
}

vars/myCustomStep.groovy

groovy
Copy
Download
def call(Map config) {
    node {
        echo "Executing myCustomStep with param: ${config.param}"
        // Access src classes
        def utils = new org.example.Utilities(this)
        utils.build(config.project)
    }
}

3. Configuring Jenkins to Use the Library

  1. Go to Manage Jenkins → Configure System

  2. Under Global Pipeline Libraries, add your library:

    • Name: my-shared-library

    • Default version: main (or your branch)

    • Retrieval method: Modern SCM

    • Source Code Management: Git

    • Project Repository: your repo URL

4. Using the Library in Jenkinsfile

groovy
Copy
Download
@Library('my-shared-library') _

pipeline {
    agent any
    stages {
        stage('Example') {
            steps {
                myCustomStep param: 'value', project: 'my-project'
            }
        }
    }
}

Debugging Groovy Code

Debugging in VS Code

  1. Setup:

    • Install the "Groovy" extension

    • Install the "Debugger for Java" extension (works for Groovy too)

  2. Configuration:

    • Create .vscode/launch.json:

    json
    Copy
    Download
    {
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "type": "groovy",
            "request": "launch",
            "name": "Debug Groovy Script",
            "program": "${workspaceFolder}/path/to/your/script.groovy"
        }
    ]
}

  3. Debugging:

    • Set breakpoints in your Groovy files

    • Press F5 to start debugging

Debugging in IntelliJ IDEA

  1. Setup:

    • Install IntelliJ IDEA Ultimate (has better Groovy support)

    • Ensure Groovy plugin is enabled

  2. Create a Run/Debug Configuration:

    • Go to Run → Edit Configurations

    • Add a new Groovy configuration

    • Specify the main Groovy script to run

  3. Debugging:

    • Set breakpoints by clicking in the gutter

    • Right-click the script → Debug 'YourScriptName'

    • Use the debug toolbar to step through code

Debugging Jenkins Shared Libraries

For debugging libraries in actual Jenkins pipelines:

  1. Replay Mode:

    • Run your pipeline once

    • Use the "Replay" feature to modify and rerun with changes

  2. Logging:

    • Use echo statements extensively

    • Add @NonCPS annotation to methods that don't need CPS transformation for better stack traces

  3. Unit Testing:

    • Use Jenkins Pipeline Unit testing framework

    • Example test:

    groovy
    Copy
    Download
    class MyLibraryTest extends BasePipelineTest {
    @Override
    @Before
    void setUp() throws Exception {
        super.setUp()
        // Load your library
        helper.registerSharedLibrary(
            library('my-shared-library@main')
        )
    }
    
    @Test
    void testMyStep() {
        def script = loadScript("vars/myCustomStep.groovy")
        script.call(param: 'test', project: 'test-project')
        // Add assertions
    }
}

  4. Remote Debugging (Advanced):

    • Start Jenkins with debug options:

      Copy
      Download
      JAVA_OPTS="-agentlib:jdwp=transport=dt_socket,server=y,suspend=n,address=5005"

    • Connect your IDE to port 5005

def call(Map config) { node { echo "Executing myCustomStep with param: ${config.param}" // Access src classes def utils = new org.example.Utilities(this) utils.build(config.project) } } can you explain this code , as per my understanding ... here in config we pass the jenkins file correct .. want to understand complete flow

Let me explain this Groovy code from a Jenkins Shared Library in detail, including the complete flow from Jenkinsfile to execution.

Code Breakdown: myCustomStep.groovy

groovy
Copy
Download
def call(Map config) {
    node {
        echo "Executing myCustomStep with param: ${config.param}"
        // Access src classes
        def utils = new org.example.Utilities(this)
        utils.build(config.project)
    }
}

1. The call Method

  • This is the entry point for your custom step when used in a Jenkinsfile

  • The Map config parameter receives parameters passed from the Jenkinsfile

  • In Groovy, when you define call(), it allows the step to be invoked directly by name

2. The node Block

  • Wraps the execution in a Jenkins agent/node context

  • Allocate an executor (runs on any available agent matching your label requirements)

  • Creates a workspace directory for this execution

3. The config Parameter

  • Receives a Map (key-value pairs) from the Jenkinsfile

  • Example: When called like myCustomStep param: 'value', project: 'my-project', the config Map will be:

    groovy
    Copy
    Download
    [param: 'value', project: 'my-project']

4. Class Instantiation

groovy
Copy
Download
def utils = new org.example.Utilities(this)

  • Creates an instance of your utility class from src/

  • this passes the Pipeline steps object (script context) to the Utilities class

  • This enables the Utilities class to use Jenkins steps like echo, sh, etc.

5. Method Invocation

groovy
Copy
Download
utils.build(config.project)

  • Calls the build() method on your Utilities instance

  • Passes the project value from the config Map

Complete Flow Example

1. Jenkinsfile

groovy
Copy
Download
@Library('my-shared-library') _

pipeline {
    agent any
    stages {
        stage('Build') {
            steps {
                // This calls your custom step
                myCustomStep(
                    param: 'hello',
                    project: 'web-app'
                )
            }
        }
    }
}

2. Execution Flow

  1. Jenkins loads the shared library (@Library directive)

  2. Pipeline reaches myCustomStep and looks for vars/myCustomStep.groovy

  3. Calls the call() method with the provided Map:

    groovy
    Copy
    Download
    [param: 'hello', project: 'web-app']

  4. The step allocates a node (agent) and workspace

  5. Outputs "Executing myCustomStep with param: hello"

  6. Creates Utilities instance, passing the Pipeline context

  7. Calls utils.build('web-app')

3. Utilities Class Execution

Assuming this implementation in src/org/example/Utilities.groovy:

groovy
Copy
Download
package org.example

class Utilities implements Serializable {
    def steps  // Pipeline steps object
    
    Utilities(steps) {
        this.steps = steps
    }
    
    def build(String projectName) {
        steps.echo "Building ${projectName}"
        steps.sh "echo 'Pretend build command for ${projectName}'"
    }
}

The output would be:

Copy
Download
[Pipeline] node
Running on Jenkins-Agent-1 in /workspace/job-name
[Pipeline] {
[Pipeline] echo
Executing myCustomStep with param: hello
[Pipeline] echo
Building web-app
[Pipeline] sh
+ echo 'Pretend build command for web-app'
Pretend build command for web-app
[Pipeline] }
[Pipeline] // node

Key Concepts

  1. vars/ Directory Magic:

    • Files in vars/ become automatically available as Pipeline steps

    • The filename becomes the step name (myCustomStep.groovy → myCustomStep)

    • Must contain a call() method to be invocable

  2. Passing Pipeline Context:

    • this in new Utilities(this) passes the Pipeline steps object

    • This is why Utilities can call steps.echo and steps.sh

  3. Serialization:

    • The implements Serializable is important for Pipeline resume/save functionality

    • Jenkins may pause and resume Pipeline execution

  4. Parameter Handling:

    • The Map parameter approach provides named parameters

    • Alternative: You could use positional parameters with def call(String param, String project)

can you explain me use of this .....src/org/example/Utilities.groovy if we have just vars folder and grooy files will that do ....?

Great question! Let me explain the purpose of the src/ folder versus just using vars/, and when you might need each approach.

vars/ Only Approach (Simpler)

If you only use the vars/ folder, your shared library would:

  • Contain Groovy scripts that define Pipeline steps directly

  • Be simpler to set up for basic use cases

  • Look like this:

Copy
Download
my-shared-library/
└── vars/
    ├── deployApp.groovy
    └── runTests.groovy

Example vars/deployApp.groovy:

groovy
Copy
Download
def call(String environment) {
    node {
        echo "Deploying to ${environment}"
        sh "./deploy.sh --env ${environment}"
    }
}

When to use just vars/:

  • For simple, self-contained Pipeline steps

  • When you don't need complex logic or code reuse

  • For quick utilities that don't require OOP structure

src/ + vars/ Approach (More Structured)

The src/ folder becomes useful when you need:

  1. Code reuse across multiple Pipeline steps

  2. Object-oriented organization of complex logic

  3. Proper unit testing (classes are easier to test)

  4. Shared functionality between different steps

Your original structure:

Copy
Download
my-shared-library/
├── src/
│   └── org/
│       └── example/
│           └── Utilities.groovy
└── vars/
    └── myCustomStep.groovy

Key Advantages of src/:

  1. Reusable Business Logic:

    • The Utilities class can contain methods used by multiple steps

    • Example: Both deployStep and rollbackStep could use the same validation method

  2. Better Organization:

    • Complex logic stays in properly organized packages

    • vars/ files remain clean and focused on Pipeline integration

  3. Testability:

    • Classes in src/ can be unit tested independently of Jenkins

    • Example test for Utilities:

    groovy
    Copy
    Download
    def "test build method"() {
    given: "a mock steps object"
    def mockSteps = [echo: { println it }, sh: { println "sh: $it" }]
    
    when: "calling build"
    new Utilities(mockSteps).build("my-project")
    
    then: "no exceptions thrown"
    notThrown(Exception)
}

  4. State Management:

    • Classes can maintain state across method calls (when properly serialized)

Practical Example: When You'd Need src/

Imagine you have:

  • Multiple deployment steps that all need to:

    1. Validate inputs

    2. Check environment health

    3. Handle errors consistently

With src/ folder:

groovy
Copy
Download
// src/org/example/DeployUtils.groovy
package org.example

class DeployUtils implements Serializable {
    def steps
    
    DeployUtils(steps) { this.steps = steps }
    
    def validate(String env) {
        if (!['dev', 'prod'].contains(env)) {
            throw new Exception("Invalid environment")
        }
    }
    
    def checkHealth() {
        steps.sh './health-check.sh'
    }
}
groovy
Copy
Download
// vars/deployToDev.groovy
def call() {
    node {
        def utils = new org.example.DeployUtils(this)
        utils.validate('dev')
        // ... dev-specific steps
    }
}
groovy
Copy
Download
// vars/deployToProd.groovy 
def call() {
    node {
        def utils = new org.example.DeployUtils(this)
        utils.validate('prod')
        // ... prod-specific steps
    }
}

When You Can Skip src/

You don't need src/ if:

  • Your steps are completely independent

  • You're just wrapping simple sequences of Pipeline steps

  • You don't need shared utility methods

  • Example where vars/ is enough:

groovy
Copy
Download
// vars/hello.groovy
def call(String name) {
    echo "Hello ${name}"
    sh "echo 'Hello ${name}' > greeting.txt"
}

Recommendation

Start with just vars/ for simple libraries. Add src/ when you:

  1. Find yourself copying code between vars/ scripts

  2. Need proper unit testing

  3. Have complex logic that benefits from OOP

  4. Want to share common functionality across steps

Would you like me to show a more complex example demonstrating the benefits of the src/ approach?

ok

Here's a more complex real-world example that demonstrates why you'd want to use the src/ folder alongside vars/ in a Jenkins Shared Library:

Example: CI/CD Pipeline for Microservices

Library Structure

Copy
Download
shared-library/
├── src/
│   └── com/
│       └── yourcompany/
│           ├── DockerUtils.groovy
│           ├── K8sDeployer.groovy
│           └── TestRunner.groovy
└── vars/
    ├── buildMicroservice.groovy
    ├── deployToK8s.groovy
    └── runIntegrationTests.groovy

1. src/ Classes (Reusable Components)

src/com/yourcompany/DockerUtils.groovy

groovy
Copy
Download
package com.yourcompany

class DockerUtils implements Serializable {
    def steps
    def registryUrl
    
    DockerUtils(steps, registryUrl) {
        this.steps = steps
        this.registryUrl = registryUrl
    }
    
    def buildImage(String imageName, String dockerfilePath='Dockerfile') {
        steps.sh """
            docker build -t ${registryUrl}/${imageName}:${steps.env.BUILD_NUMBER} \
            -f ${dockerfilePath} .
        """
    }
    
    def pushImage(String imageName) {
        steps.sh "docker push ${registryUrl}/${imageName}:${steps.env.BUILD_NUMBER}"
    }
    
    def loginToRegistry() {
        steps.withCredentials([steps.usernamePassword(
            credentialsId: 'docker-creds',
            usernameVariable: 'DOCKER_USER',
            passwordVariable: 'DOCKER_PASS'
        )]) {
            steps.sh """
                echo \$DOCKER_PASS | docker login -u \$DOCKER_USER --password-stdin ${registryUrl}
            """
        }
    }
}

src/com/yourcompany/K8sDeployer.groovy

groovy
Copy
Download
package com.yourcompany

class K8sDeployer implements Serializable {
    def steps
    
    K8sDeployer(steps) {
        this.steps = steps
    }
    
    def deploy(String namespace, String deploymentFile, Map replacements) {
        String processedFile = processTemplate(deploymentFile, replacements)
        steps.writeFile file: 'temp_deployment.yaml', text: processedFile
        steps.sh "kubectl apply -f temp_deployment.yaml -n ${namespace}"
    }
    
    private String processTemplate(String filePath, Map replacements) {
        String content = steps.readFile(filePath)
        replacements.each { k, v ->
            content = content.replaceAll("\\\${${k}}", v.toString())
        }
        return content
    }
}

2. vars/ Steps (Pipeline Interfaces)

vars/buildMicroservice.groovy

groovy
Copy
Download
def call(Map config) {
    node('docker') {
        def docker = new com.yourcompany.DockerUtils(this, config.registryUrl)
        docker.loginToRegistry()
        docker.buildImage(config.imageName)
        docker.pushImage(config.imageName)
    }
}

vars/deployToK8s.groovy

groovy
Copy
Download
def call(Map config) {
    node('k8s-master') {
        def k8s = new com.yourcompany.K8sDeployer(this)
        def imageTag = "${config.registryUrl}/${config.imageName}:${env.BUILD_NUMBER}"
        
        k8s.deploy(
            namespace: config.namespace,
            deploymentFile: config.deploymentTemplate,
            replacements: [
                APP_NAME: config.appName,
                IMAGE_TAG: imageTag,
                REPLICAS: config.replicas
            ]
        )
    }
}

3. Jenkinsfile Usage

groovy
Copy
Download
@Library('shared-library@main') _

pipeline {
    agent none
    stages {
        stage('Build') {
            steps {
                buildMicroservice(
                    registryUrl: 'registry.yourcompany.com',
                    imageName: 'auth-service'
                )
            }
        }
        stage('Deploy to Staging') {
            steps {
                deployToK8s(
                    namespace: 'staging',
                    imageName: 'auth-service',
                    registryUrl: 'registry.yourcompany.com',
                    appName: 'auth-service',
                    replicas: 2,
                    deploymentTemplate: 'k8s/auth-deployment.yaml'
                )
            }
        }
    }
}

Why This Structure Works Well

  1. Code Reuse:

    • Multiple teams can use the same DockerUtils class with different parameters

    • The Kubernetes deployment logic is centralized but customizable

  2. Separation of Concerns:

    • src/ contains business logic (Docker/K8s operations)

    • vars/ contains Pipeline-specific integration

  3. Testability:

    groovy
    Copy
    Download
    // Example unit test for DockerUtils
def "test image building"() {
    given: "a mock steps object"
    def mockSteps = [
        sh: { cmd -> println "Executing: $cmd" },
        env: [BUILD_NUMBER: '123']
    ]
    
    when: "building an image"
    new DockerUtils(mockSteps, 'my-registry.com')
        .buildImage('my-service')
    
    then: "no exceptions thrown"
    notThrown(Exception)
}

  4. Maintainability:

    • If Docker CLI changes, you only update DockerUtils

    • If Kubernetes API changes, you only update K8sDeployer

  5. Consistency:

    • All teams use the same standardized Docker/K8s operations

    • Enforces company-wide best practices

Key Takeaways

  1. Use src/ when:

    • You have complex business logic

    • Multiple steps share common functionality

    • You need proper unit testing

    • You want to enforce standards across teams

  2. Use vars/ for:

    • Pipeline step definitions

    • Simple step implementations

    • Gluing together src/ classes in Pipeline context

  3. The magic happens when:

    • vars/ scripts act as "controllers" that orchestrate

    • src/ classes act as "services" that contain business logic

This architecture scales well for large organizations with many teams and complex deployment requirements. Would you like me to show how to add another service (like database migrations) to this structure?

Here's a clear explanation of the workflow and relationship between src/ and vars/ with diagrams:

1. Visual Workflow (Sequence Diagram)

│     │

│           ├─▶ docker push
│           └─▶ docker login
│
└─▶ vars/deployToK8s.groovy (Pipeline Step)
      │
      └─▶ src/com/yourcompany/K8sDeployer.groovy (Class)
            ├─▶ kubectl apply
            └─▶ template processing

2. Communication Flow

3. Concrete Example Walkthrough

Let's trace a complete execution with the microservice example:

Step 1: Jenkinsfile Triggers vars/ Script

groovy
Copy
Download
buildMicroservice(
    registryUrl: 'registry.acme.com',
    imageName: 'user-service'
)

Step 2: vars/buildMicroservice.groovy Handles Pipeline Context

groovy
Copy
Download
// In vars/buildMicroservice.groovy
def call(Map config) {
    node('docker') {
        // 1. Initialize src/ class WITH pipeline context ('this')
        def docker = new com.yourcompany.DockerUtils(this, config.registryUrl)
        
        // 2. Call src/ class methods
        docker.loginToRegistry()
        docker.buildImage(config.imageName)
        docker.pushImage(config.imageName)
    }
}

Step 3: src/DockerUtils.groovy Executes Business Logic

groovy
Copy
Download
// In src/com/yourcompany/DockerUtils.groovy
def buildImage(String imageName) {
    // Uses the passed pipeline steps ('steps' = 'this' from vars/)
    steps.sh """
        docker build -t ${registryUrl}/${imageName}:${steps.env.BUILD_NUMBER} .
    """
}

4. Key Interaction Points

  1. Initialization (vars → src):

    groovy
    Copy
    Download
    // vars script creates src class instance
def utils = new com.yourcompany.Utilities(this)

    • this passes the Jenkins Pipeline context (steps object)

  2. Method Calling (vars → src):

    groovy
    Copy
    Download
    // vars script calls src class methods
utils.build(config.project)

  3. Accessing Jenkins (src → vars context):

    groovy
    Copy
    Download
    // Inside src class
steps.echo "Building..."  // 'steps' is the passed Pipeline context
steps.sh "make ${target}"

5. When Communication Happens

PhaseLocationResponsibility
Pipeline TriggerJenkinsfileCalls vars/ scripts with parameters
Pipeline Executionvars/ scriptManages Jenkins nodes/stages
Business Logicsrc/ classPerforms complex operations
System Interactionsrc/ classExecutes commands (docker, kubectl etc)

6. Visual Analogy

Think of it like a restaurant:

  • Jenkinsfile = Customer (orders food)

  • vars/ = Waiter (takes order, serves food)

  • src/ = Chef (prepares food using kitchen tools)

  • Jenkins Environment = Kitchen tools

The waiter (vars/):

  1. Takes order from customer (parameters)

  2. Goes to chef (src/) and gives instructions

  3. Chef uses kitchen tools (Jenkins steps) to prepare

  4. Waiter delivers final result

7. Why This Separation Matters

  1. vars/ scripts:

    • Know about Jenkins Pipeline syntax (node, stage, etc.)

    • Handle Pipeline-specific concerns (workspace, agents)

    • Are simple glue code

  2. src/ classes:

    • Are completely Jenkins-agnostic

    • Contain pure business logic

    • Can be tested without Jenkins

    • Can be reused outside Pipelines

Here's a complete end-to-end workflow diagram with Jenkins as the orchestrator, showing the entire sequence from triggering a build to final execution:

End-to-End Jenkins Shared Library Workflow

Diagram
Code
Download

Detailed Step-by-Step Explanation

1. User Triggers Pipeline

  • Action: Click "Build Now" in Jenkins UI or Git webhook triggers the job.

  • Jenkins:

    • Parses the Jenkinsfile

    • Loads the Shared Library (@Library directive)

2. Jenkins Calls vars/ Script

  • Example:

    groovy
    Copy
    Download
    buildMicroservice(registryUrl: "my-registry.com", imageName: "auth-service")

  • What Happens:

    • Jenkins looks for vars/buildMicroservice.groovy in the Shared Library

    • Executes the call() method in the script

3. vars/ Script Initializes src/ Class

  • Code in vars/buildMicroservice.groovy:

    groovy
    Copy
    Download
    def docker = new com.yourcompany.DockerUtils(this, config.registryUrl)

  • Key Point:

    • this passes Jenkins pipeline context (steps object) to the src/ class.

4. src/ Class Executes Business Logic

  • Example: DockerUtils.buildImage() runs:

    groovy
    Copy
    Download
    steps.sh "docker build -t ${imageName} ."

  • Jenkins Role:

    • The steps object (passed from vars/) allows src/ to run Jenkins DSL commands (sh, echo, etc.)

5. External System Interaction

  • Examples:

    • docker build → Docker Daemon

    • kubectl apply → Kubernetes Cluster

    • curl → REST API

6. Results Propagate Back

  • Success:

    • src/ returns control to vars/

    • vars/ moves to the next step

  • Failure:

    • Throws exception → Jenkins fails the stage

7. Jenkins Completes Pipeline

  • Final Steps:

    • Updates build status

    • Sends notifications (email/Slack)

    • Archives artifacts (if any)

Key Takeaways

StepComponentResponsibility
1JenkinsTriggers pipeline, loads library
2vars/Pipeline step entry point, manages Jenkins context (node, stage)
3src/Reusable business logic (Docker/K8s/API calls)
4ExternalExecutes actual commands (docker, kubectl, etc.)

Visual Workflow Summary

[User] 
  → [Jenkins] (Starts pipeline) 
    → [vars/] (Orchestrates steps) 
      → [src/] (Runs business logic) 
        → [External Systems] (Docker/K8s) 
      ← [src/] (Returns result) 
    ← [vars/] (Updates stage status) 
  ← [Jenkins] (Completes build)

Yes! Jenkins will capture and propagate errors from external systems (like Docker, Kubernetes, or APIs) back through the shared library workflow. Here's exactly how it happens:

Error Propagation from External Systems to Jenkins

    steps.sh "docker build -t my-image ."  // ← If this fails

2. Error Flow

Download
Docker CLI (fails with exit code 1)
 → Jenkins `sh` step catches the exit code 
  → Throws `ProcessExitedException` 
   → Bubble up through src/ class 
    → vars/ script rethrows 
     → Jenkins marks stage as FAILED

What Jenkins Captures

Error SourceHow Jenkins Sees ItExample Console Output
Docker FailureNon-zero exit code from docker commandERROR: The command '/bin/sh -c apt-get install invalid-package' returned a non-zero code: 100
K8s Failurekubectl error messageERROR: Error from server (NotFound): deployments.apps "my-app" not found
Network IssueSocket timeout/connection refusedERROR: Get "https://registry-1.docker.io/v2/": dial tcp: lookup registry-1.docker.io: no such host

Key Mechanisms

1. Shell Step (sh) Behavior

  • Any command returning exit code != 0 fails the step.

  • Example:

How to Access Detailed External Errors

def buildImage() {
    try {
        steps.sh script: "docker build -t my-image .", returnStdout: true
    } catch (Exception e) {
        echo "Docker failed with: ${e.message}"
        // Access full error:
        def errorLog = steps.sh(
            script: "docker build -t my-image . 2>&1", 
            returnStatus: true, 
            returnStdout: true
        )
        echo "Full error log: ${errorLog}"
        throw e  // Re-throw to fail the stage
    }
}

Best Practices for Error Handling

  1. Wrap External Calls in try/catch (in src/ classes):

    groovy

        steps.sh "docker build..."
    } catch (Exception e) {
        echo "Docker error: ${e.message}"
        throw e  // Re-throw to fail the stage
    }
}

  2. Add Context to Errors:

    Download

  3. Use post { failure { ... } } (in Jenkinsfile):

    groovy
    Copy
    Download

    failure {
        slackSend "Build failed in ${currentBuild.fullDisplayName}"
    }
}

Summary

  • Jenkins propagates ALL external errors (Docker/K8s/APIs) through the shared library.

  • Use returnStdout and returnStatus to capture detailed error logs.

  • Always re-throw exceptions after logging to ensure Jenkins fails the build.

Here's a comprehensive approach to auto-rectify Docker failures in Jenkins Shared Libraries, covering different failure scenarios with actionable recovery strategies:

1. Smart Error Classification & Auto-Recovery Workflow

Diagram
Code
Download

2. Implementation in Shared Library

src/com/utils/DockerSmartUtils.groovy

groovy
Copy
Download
package com.utils

class DockerSmartUtils implements Serializable {
    def steps
    private int maxRetries = 3
    private int retryDelay = 5 // seconds

    DockerSmartUtils(steps) {
        this.steps = steps
    }

    def buildWithRecovery(Map config) {
        int attempt = 0
        while (attempt < maxRetries) {
            try {
                steps.echo "Attempt ${attempt + 1} of ${maxRetries}"
                return steps.sh(
                    script: "docker build -t ${config.imageTag} ${config.dockerfilePath}",
                    returnStdout: true
                )
            } catch (Exception e) {
                attempt++
                handleDockerError(e, config)
                if (attempt >= maxRetries) throw e
                steps.sleep(retryDelay)
            }
        }
    }

    private void handleDockerError(Exception e, Map config) {
        String errorMsg = e.toString()
        steps.echo "Docker Error: ${errorMsg}"

        // Case 1: Invalid Dockerfile path
        if (errorMsg.contains("Cannot locate Dockerfile")) {
            config.dockerfilePath = "./Dockerfile" // Reset to default
            steps.echo "Auto-corrected Dockerfile path to default"
        }
        // Case 2: Docker daemon not responding
        else if (errorMsg.contains("Cannot connect to the Docker daemon")) {
            steps.sh "sudo systemctl restart docker"
            steps.echo "Restarted Docker daemon"
        }
        // Case 3: Image pull failure
        else if (errorMsg.contains("pull access denied")) {
            config.imageTag = "fallback-registry.com/${config.imageTag}"
            steps.echo "Switched to fallback registry"
        }
    }
}

3. Usage in vars/buildApp.groovy

groovy
Copy
Download
def call(Map config) {
    def docker = new com.utils.DockerSmartUtils(this)
    
    try {
        docker.buildWithRecovery([
            imageTag: "${config.imageName}:${env.BUILD_NUMBER}",
            dockerfilePath: config.dockerfilePath ?: "./Dockerfile"
        ])
    } catch (Exception e) {
        steps.slackSend "Build failed after retries: ${e.message}"
        error "Docker build failed irrecoverably"
    }
}

    passwordVariable: 'REG_PASS'

        echo \$REG_PASS | docker login -u \$REG_USER --password-stdin private-registry.com
    """
}

5. Advanced Recovery Patterns

Exponential Backoff Retry

groovy
Copy
Download
private void retryWithBackoff(Closure operation) {
    int attempt = 0
    while (attempt < maxRetries) {
        try {
            operation()
            return
        } catch (Exception e) {
            attempt++
            int delay = Math.pow(2, attempt).intValue() // 2,4,8,... sec
            steps.echo "Retrying in ${delay} seconds..."
            steps.sleep(delay)
        }
    }
    throw new Exception("All retries failed")
}

Health Check Before Retry

groovy
Copy
Download
private boolean isDockerHealthy() {
    def status = steps.sh(
        script: "sudo docker info >/dev/null 2>&1 && echo OK || echo FAIL",
        returnStdout: true
    ).trim()
    return status == "OK"
}

                )

Key Takeaways

  1. Classify Errors:

    • Use error message patterns to identify failure types

  2. Hierarchical Recovery:

    • Simple fixes first (path correction)

    • System-level fixes next (daemon restart)

    • Fallback strategies last (alternate registries)

  3. Safe Retries:

    • Limit attempts with maxRetries

    • Add delays between retries

  4. Observability:

    • Log all recovery actions

    • Notify on final failure

  5. Idempotent Operations:

    • Ensure recovery actions can be safely repeated

For production systems, combine this with:

  • Circuit Breakers (stop retrying if infrastructure is down)

  • Metric Collection (track failure patterns)

  • Manual Override Flags (skip auto-recovery when needed)

def verifyDockerState() {

    def unhealthy = psOutput.readLines().findAll { !it.contains('healthy') }
    if (unhealthy) {

        return false
    }
    return true
}

def safeRestartDocker() {
    // 1. Drain node (if in cluster)
    steps.sh "kubectl drain ${env.NODE_NAME} --ignore-daemonsets"
    
    // 2. Stateful service check
    if (isStatefulServiceRunning()) {
        migrateStatefulWorkloads()

    steps.sh """
    sudo systemctl stop docker
    sudo rm -f /var/lib/docker/network/files/local-kv.db
    sudo systemctl start docker
    """

Here's a strategic approach to identify and eliminate duplication across 15+ pipelines in a shared library's vars/ directory, along with tools to build a business case for management:

1. Quick Duplication Detection Script

Run this Groovy script locally on your cloned shared library to find duplicate functions:

groovy
Copy
Download
#!/usr/bin/env groovy

import groovy.json.JsonOutput

def libraryDir = new File("path/to/your/shared-library")
def varsDir = new File(libraryDir, "vars")
def duplicates = [:].withDefault { [] }

// Step 1: Find all .groovy files in vars/
varsDir.eachFile { file ->
    if (file.name.endsWith('.groovy')) {
        def content = file.text
        
        // Extract call() methods (simplified regex)
        def methods = (content =~ /def\s+(call|[\w]+)\s*\(([^)]*)\)\s*\{([^\}]*)\}/)
        
        methods.each { match ->
            def methodName = match[1]
            def methodBody = match[3].trim()
            duplicates[methodBody] << "${file.name}:${methodName}"
        }
    }
}

// Step 2: Filter real duplicates (same body in 2+ files)
def realDuplicates = duplicates.findAll { k, v -> v.size() > 1 }

// Generate report
new File("duplication_report.html").withWriter { writer ->
    writer << """
    <html><body>
    <h1>Shared Library Duplication Report</h1>
    <p>Scanned ${varsDir.listFiles().size()} files in vars/</p>
    <h2>${realDuplicates.size()} Duplicate Functions Found</h2>
    <table border="1">
    <tr><th>Function Body Hash</th><th>Locations</th><th>Sample Code</th></tr>
    """
    
    realDuplicates.each { body, locations ->
        writer << """
        <tr>
            <td>${body.hashCode()}</td>
            <td>${locations.join('<br>')}</td>
            <td><pre>${body.take(200).escapeHtml()}</pre></td>
        </tr>
        """
    }
    
    writer << "</table></body></html>"
}

println "Report generated: duplication_report.html"

How to Run:

  1. Save as find_dupes.groovy

  2. groovy find_dupes.groovy

  3. Open HTML report in browser

Copy
Download
abstract class BasePipeline {
    abstract void build()
    
    protected parseLogs() { /* shared */ }
}

class MavenPipeline extends BasePipeline {
    void build() {
        super.parseLogs()
        // Maven-specific logic
    }
}

Phase 3: Composition Over Inheritance

groovy
Copy
Download
class MavenPipeline {
    private final BuildExecutor executor
    
    MavenPipeline(steps) {
        this.executor = new MavenExecutor(steps)
    }
    
    def build() {
        executor.run()
        new SecurityScanner(steps).scan()
    }
}
